LEXDomains.LEXDomain: Groups and Classes of Persons and Members of Such Groups and Classes

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: a person not participating in Greek culture and civilization (βάρβαρος contrasts with {L:Ἕλλην<SDBG:Ἕλλην:000000>}[a] ‘Greek,’ {D:11.90}, with the focus on culture rather than on language; see {S:04601401100024} at {D:11.94})
LEXSense.Comments: It would be a mistake in the case of {S:04500101400008} to speak merely of ‘Greeks and barbarians’ or ‘Greeks and savages.’ By NT times {L:Ἕλλην<SDBG:Ἕλλην:000000>} (see {D:11.90}) would have included most of those who participated in one way or another in the culture of the Greco-Roman world. Accordingly, one may render the contrast in {S:04500101400008} as ‘the civilized and the uncivilized.’

LEXDomains.LEXDomain: Groups and Classes of Persons and Members of Such Groups and Classes

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: the native people of an area in which a language other than Greek or Latin was spoken (such persons would be regarded as being outside the civilized world of NT times)
LEXSense.Comments: In rendering this expression in {S:04402800200006} it would be possible in some languages to translate ‘the people there who spoke a strange language were friendly to us’ or ‘the local inhabitants of that island were kind to us.’ ἔσομαι τῷ λαλοῦντι βάρβαρος καὶ ὁ λαλῶν ἐν ἐμοὶ βάρβαρος ‘I will be a foreigner to the one who speaks, and the one who speaks will be a foreigner to me’ {S:04601401100036}. In {S:04601401100036} βάρβαρος implies being a foreigner from a country outside of the so-called civilized world.

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: a pattern of behavior associated with a low cultural level
LEXSense.Comments: Regardless of the level of culture or civilization, each ethnic group seems to be able to point to some other group regarded as being uncivilized. In some languages such a group is identified as ‘those who live far away’ or ‘those who do not live in towns’ or ‘those who are very strange.’ In {S:05100301100020} {L:Σκύθης<SDBG:Σκύθης:000000>} ‘Scythian’ ({D:93.583}) may represent a state of civilization even lower than that implied by βάρβαρος ‘barbarian.’
